==Application Bundles==
==Application Bundles==
â
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:iTunes Contents.png|thumb|right|A Finder window displaying the contents of a typical Mac OS X application bundle.]] -->
 
Application bundles are often presented to users as a single file known as a "[[Software package (installation)|package]]". This file is really a directory ending in a <tt>.app</tt> extension. Control-clicking (or right-clicking) on the package and selecting "Show Package Contents" allows a user to open up the bundle and see the contents. In an application, the first directory in the bundle is usually <tt>Contents</tt>; within contents there is usually another directory with the executable code (called <tt>MacOS</tt> for Macs, or the application's name for GNUstep), which contains the application's executable code, and a directory called <tt>Resources</tt>, which contains the resources of the application.
Application bundles are often presented to users as a single file known as a "[[Software package (installation)|package]]". This file is really a directory ending in a <tt>.app</tt> extension. Control-clicking (or right-clicking) on the package and selecting "Show Package Contents" allows a user to open up the bundle and see the contents. In an application, the first directory in the bundle is usually <tt>Contents</tt>; within contents there is usually another directory with the executable code (called <tt>MacOS</tt> for Macs, or the application's name for GNUstep), which contains the application's executable code, and a directory called <tt>Resources</tt>, which contains the resources of the application.
